p: Bleeding in gastrointestinal tract is typically seen in patients with profound or prolonged shock complicated by metabolic acidosis and/or DIC. Minor epistaxis, gum bleeding, and gastrointestinal bleeding are sometimes observed in children without shock ( Carlos et al., 2005), but bleeding from mucosal surfaces tends to be both more common and more severe in adult. Intracranial hemorrhage is a very rare but often fatal complication ( Wani et al., 2010).
